awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Resilient Seismic Retrofit by Integrating Selective Weakening and Self-Centering
awd_abstract_narration:
The occurrence of a major seismic event, although low in probability, carries high risk. Many reinforced concrete buildings in the United States and around the world were built before the implementation of modern seismic design codes. Based on seismic events of recent history outside the United States, significant economic losses can be expected in the United States if similar events occur near densely populated cities. Reducing economic losses, shortening time to recovery, and returning to normal operation levels are essential and define resiliency against seismic hazard.  Existing seismic retrofit methods achieve life safety through permanent damage. This project will investigate a new seismic retrofit method which focuses on not only public safety but also on resiliency by minimizing damage. The new retrofit system will be applicable to buildings with sub-standard reinforced concrete shear walls as the lateral load resisting system. Low damage ensures that buildings can remain operational and habitable within a reasonable amount of time following an earthquake, while keeping the socio-economic losses related to the building stock to a minimum compared to systems retrofitted with traditional methods. The retrofit method can also be architecturally advantageous for cases where the scope or budget for additional lateral load resisting systems is not available. Education, outreach, and technology transfer activities will focus on raising awareness about resiliency, multiple hazards, and new building technologies, as well as increasing participation of underrepresented groups in STEM. 

In this project, a new seismic retrofit method, integrating the concepts of selective weakening, hinged walls, and self-centering, will be investigated to achieve low seismic damage. The method will be targeted toward improving the performance of reinforced concrete shear walls that have design deficiencies related to confinement, transverse reinforcement, and reinforcement detailing, which have been associated with slender wall failures in past earthquakes. The retrofit method will involve converting traditional and deficient shear walls into self-centering walls by creating a cold joint near the shear wall-foundation interface (weakening) and adding unbonded external post-tensioning. The objective of this research is to understand the change in fundamental response of deficient reinforced concrete buildings when retrofitted with this method. Research methods to achieve this objective will include element and system level structural testing and analysis. Element level studies will include nonlinear analytical modeling and testing of retrofitted shear walls under reverse cyclic loading. These studies will identify viable retrofit details and target shear wall deficiencies. System level investigations will include finite element and time-history analyses to understand the interaction of retrofitted shear walls with other structural elements to control damage to these elements. Performance enhancement that can be achieved by this retrofit method will be quantified using reliability concepts. This work will create a fundamental understanding of building systems retrofitted with this method in terms of capacity, hysteretic response, and self-centering capability through nonlinear analyses, testing, and fragility studies. The findings of this research also will have the potential to advance the state-of-the-art of self-centering structures that are newly constructed. Project outcomes will produce new basic knowledge needed to retrofit deficient concrete walls and develop more resilient buildings in seismic regions and thus contribute to seismic hazard mitigation in the United States and around the world. Project data will be made available in the NHERI Data Depot at https://www.designsafe-ci.org/.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Many reinforced concrete buildings that were built before the adoption of modern seismic design codes need retrofitting to be ready for the next seismic event. A new retrofit method is investigated for reinforced concrete shear walls, a very common lateral load resisting system in buildings. The objective of the new retrofit method is to achieve minimal structural damage, in addition to life safety. Minimizing structural damage is one key component of resiliency as reduced damage may lower building downtimes and repair costs after an extreme event, allowing rapid recovery from a seismic hazard and rapid return to functionality. In this project, the new retrofit method was investigated for reinforced concrete buildings with slender shear walls that do not carry significant gravity loading. The new method involves allowing traditionally built older shear walls to have controlled rocking and recentering, leading to a significant reduction in a damage measure known as the residual displacement.

This research made a new retrofit method available for the engineers’ toolbox. The project provided insights on how older reinforced concrete shear walls with non-compliant details are expected to behave in an earthquake. Improvements and changes of structural behavior that are resulting from the new retrofit method are presented. New laboratory test data on large scale reinforced concrete shear wall specimens under cyclic loading were created. These data were used to evaluate the suitability of strength and displacement capacity prediction methods for building assessment and retrofit design. Numerical modeling techniques that allow visualization of wall behavior under static and dynamic cyclic loading were developed and validated using test data for retrofitted walls. Both detailed and idealized shear wall numerical models were created to visualize complete stress and strain fields for a detailed assessment of pre- and post-retrofit walls and to perform computationally demanding dynamic analyses that capture collapse. Damage was documented through testing and modeling. Numerical methods were used to identify the impact of retrofit parameters on retrofit efficacy and to run studies that reveal the working details of the retrofit. Seismic collapse risk was quantified for buildings with various characteristics before and after shear walls are retrofitted. This information can be beneficial for engineers, building owners, building insurers and other stakeholders, who share a common interest in understanding the impact of retrofit on building performance. The findings of this study were developed with a focus on retrofitting older buildings but may indirectly be beneficial for assessment of old buildings and for new building designs that utilize self-centering systems.

Two graduate students and three undergraduate students, all but one from underrepresented groups in engineering, were trained and mentored through this project on analytical and experimental research methods as well as career portfolio development. The students were actively involved in disseminating the results through publications and presentations to structural and earthquake engineering community. In addition, the project exposed K-12 students, educators and parents to earthquake engineering, performance based engineering and seismic retrofit through outreach efforts that spanned from delivering hands on demonstrations, to assisting in student competitions and to participating in career planning events. Project findings on hazard preparedness and resiliency concepts were integrated into outreach materials and tools. Some of these outreach activities were conducted in partnership with organizations (within and outside of University at Buffalo) that serve underrepresented student groups to broaden participation from these groups.


Last Modified: 11/29/2021
Modified by: Pinar Okumus
